etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in James Dana (1813–1895), geologist, zoologist, and teacher. From German Prosopit from ancient Greek πρόσωπον face, mask + German -it, so called in allusion to its deceptive (i.e. pseudomorphic) character

definitions: A fluoride mineral usually occurring as minute, tabular crystals of a colourless, white, or greyish colour, often altered into pseudomorphs such as fluorite, apatite, and kaolin.

notes.text: Prosopite consists of a fluoride and hydroxide of aluminium and calcium, CaAl₂(F,OH)₈. Crystal system: monoclinic.
